The date when Defence Minister Guido Crosetto publicly responded to a suspicious call, confirming it was a scam and initiating police involvement.
The start of a broader trend in deepfake scams, with global losses rising from $200 million in the first quarter to $347 million in the second quarter of 2025.
The release of Resemble AI's report detailing $547.2 million lost globally to deepfake scams between January and June 2025, highlighting escalating misuse of AI voice technology.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The timeframe during which deepfake-related frauds, including voice cloning scams and AI-generated sexual content, have surged globally, particularly in the US and Italy.
The projected end of the year when DeepMedia estimates 8 million deepfakes will be created and shared online, indicating a dramatic increase in synthetic media production.

keyTakeAways: AI-generated voices are now indistinguishable from real human voices, especially when cloned from real individuals, as demonstrated by research from Queen Mary University of London.

The Italian scam involving fake Defence Minister Guido Crosetto calls, which targeted wealthy businessmen including Giorgio Armani and Patrizio Bertelli, illustrates real-world risks of AI voice deepfakes.
Only Massimo Moratti, former owner of Inter Milan, sent money in the scam, and he has since filed a legal complaint with Italian authorities.
AI voice cloning uses deep learning and natural language processing to mimic pitch, accent, intonation, and even speech errors, making synthetic voices highly realistic and trustworthy.
Research shows that participants were more likely to trust AI-generated voices than real human voices, indicating a shift in public perception and a growing vulnerability.
Global losses from deepfake scams have risen significantly, with over $547 million lost between January and June 2025, including $200 million in Q1 and $347 million in Q2.

AI-generated deepfakes are being used to create non-consensual sexual content, including child sexual abuse material, which has led to new legal actions such as the US federal law banning such content.
Australia has banned an application used to generate deepfake nude images, showing growing regulatory responses to AI-generated abuse.
Positive applications include restoring speech for individuals with speech impairments, highlighting that AI voice tech can be beneficial when used ethically.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A wave of AI-powered voice scams targeting wealthy Italian businessmen has emerged, with fraudsters using deepfake technology to clone the voice of Defence Minister Guido Crosetto and request money for a fictional kidnapping of journalists. This incident, occurring shortly after Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni secured the release of journalist Cecilia Sala, highlights the growing sophistication of AI voice cloning, which can now produce voices indistinguishable from real human ones. Research from Queen Mary University of London confirms that AI-generated voice clones are rated as equally realistic as real voices and are even perceived as more trustworthy. Global losses from deepfake scams have reached over $547 million between January and June 2025, with rising misuse in fraudulent calls and non-consensual sexual content. The US and Australia have responded with new laws banning the distribution of AI-generated intimate images. While AI voice technology offers ethical benefits—such as helping individuals with speech impairments—the technology poses serious threats to personal identity, financial security, and public trust.
title: AI now sounds more like us – should we be concerned?
